review.title: Exploiting an Oracle That Reports AUC Scores in Machine Learning Contests
review.abstract: In machine learning contests such as the Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge and the KDD Cup, contestants can submit candidate solutions and receive from an oracle (typically the organizers of the competition) the accuracy of their guesses compared to (a subset of) the ground-truth labels. A commonly used accuracy metric for binary classification tasks is the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristics Curve (AUC), which is equivalent to the probability of correct response in a 2-Alternative Forced Choice (2AFC) task in which the classifier must distinguish one positively labeled example from one negatively labeled example. In this paper we illustrate how knowledge of the 2AFC score c of a set of guesses constrains the set of possible labelings that the dataset can have. We then show that the worst-case number of possible binary labelings of n examples corresponding to any particular 2AFC score c w.r.t. some candidate solution is 2^n.

One of the most commonly used accuracy metrics for binary classification tasks is the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristics Curve (AUC). In this paper, we provide concept evidence of how knowledge of the AUC of a set of guesses can be used in two different types of attacks to improve the accuracy of these guesses. On the other hand, we also demonstrate the intractability of a type of AUC exploitation by demonstrating that the number of possible binary labels of n examples for which a candidate solution receives an AUC score of c grows exponentially in n for each c (0, 1).

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: Our work relates to the problem of data leaks, i.e. the unintentional introduction of information about test data into the training data set of data mining competitions. Leakage has traditionally been identified as one of the most important data leakage errors [MNEI09] and can be surprisingly insidious and difficult to identify and prevent [KBF + 00, KRPS12]. Leakage is traditionally defined in a "static" sense, e.g. as an artifact of the data preparation process that leads to certain characteristics revealing the target label with complete certainty. Exploitation of an AUC oracle can be considered a form of "dynamic" leakage: the reaction of the oracle during the competition to a series of assumptions submitted by a participant may reveal the identity of certain test labels or at least limit the set of possible labels. Our research also relates to data-containing labels and different data protection labels (e.g., MURLA13, [MURLA11] which may be used for certain purposes].

sections.heading: Exploiting the AUC Score: A Simple Example
sections.text: As the first example of how knowledge of the AUC of a set of conjectures can reveal the basic truth tests, this is a hypothetical tiny test group of only 4 examples, so that the probability that these examples belong to the positive class is higher than the basic truth tests, for example i {1, 2, 3, 4}. Suppose a candidate estimates these conjectures through a machine learning process that the probability that these examples belong to the positive class is higher than the probability that these conjectures have an AUC of 0.75, then the candidate can almost certainly conclude that the true solution is y1 = 1, y2 = 0, y3 = 1, and y4 = 0, because this is the only basic truth test that is satisfactory.

sections.text: Proof. Without loss of generality, let's assume that the indices are arranged in such a way that the y-i examples are sorted, i.e., y-1 <.. < y-n. Suppose, as a contradiction, that m of the first k examples were positively labeled, with 1 ≤ m ≤ k. For each of these possible m, we can find at least m (n0 − k) pairs labeled incorrectly according to the real assumptions, by combining each of the m-positively labeled examples within the index range {i: 1 ≤ i ≤ k} with each of the (n0 − k) negatively labeled examples within the index range {j: k + 1 ≤ j ≤ n}. In each such pair (i, j), yi = 1 and yj = 0, and yet y-i < y-j < j < j, and thus the pair is labeled incorrectly.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have examined characteristics of the Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) that may allow a data mining contest entrant to exploit an oracle that reports AUC values in order to improperly obtain higher performance; we have presented two simple attacks: one in which a participant whose assumptions are already highly accurate can infer with absolute certainty the values of some of the test set labels; and another in which a participant can use the AUC information from the oracle to improve his / her assumptions using standard Bayesian conclusions. To our knowledge, our work is the first to formally investigate this type of attack; the practical implications of our work are mixed: on the one hand, we have presented evidence for the concept that systematic exploitation of AUC oracles is possible, underscoring the importance of simple security measures, such as (a) adding sounds to the results of the Oracle, (the AUC) the number of times a candidate can play in the Oracle, and (the AUC) the number of times a candidate can be limited in the Oracle).
